contracts.extractedText:
STATEMENT OF WORK (SOW)
Hourly Services Agreement

This SOW (“Agreement”) made and effective as of November, 2024 (the “Effective Date”) by and between Swan Softweb Solutions, LLC (“Developer ”),, and Markman Group LLC (“Client”), sets forth the agreement whereby Developer agrees to provide services to Markman Group LLC pursuant to the terms and conditions herein. 
1. SERVICES
This Statement of Work ("SOW") outlines the terms and conditions under which the Developer agrees to provide Client with hourly services as described in this Agreement. The specific nature and scope of the Services will be determined and agreed upon by both parties on a project-by-project basis, and may include, but are not limited to: software development, web development, technical support, etc..
2. HOURLY RATE
The hourly rate for the Services provided under this Agreement shall be $30.00 USD.
3. INVOICING AND PAYMENT
3.1 Developer shall invoice Client for Services rendered on a project-by-project basis, as agreed upon by both parties. Each invoice shall include a detailed breakdown of the services provided, the date(s) of service, the number of hours worked, and the total amount due.
3.2 Client shall pay each invoice within 15 days of receipt.  
3.3. Any disputed invoice amounts must be communicated to Developer in writing within 15 days of receipt. Failure to dispute an invoice within this timeframe shall constitute acceptance of the invoice.
3.4 Developer shall submit a weekly report to Client detailing the tasks performed, the number of hours spent on each task, and the status of each task. Client shall review and approve or reject the submitted hours within 7 business days. Only approved hours shall be included in the subsequent invoice.
3.5 In the event that the Client identifies errors, defects, or other issues directly attributable to the Developer´s work, the Developer shall rectify such issues at no additional cost to the Client. Hours spent by the Developer to resolve these issues shall not be included in the invoiced hours.


4. TERM AND TERMINATION
4.1. This Agreement shall commence on November, 2024 and shall continue until terminated by either party in accordance with this Section 4.
4.2. Either party may terminate this Agreement upon 30 days written notice to the other party.
4.3. Developer may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice to Client in the event of Client's failure to pay any invoice within 30 days of its due date.
5. INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR 
Developer is an independent contractor and is not an employee, agent, or partner of Client. Developer shall be solely responsible for all taxes, insurance, and other expenses related to the provision of the Services.
6. CONFIDENTIALITY 
Both parties agree to maintain the confidentiality of any proprietary or confidential information disclosed during this Agreement.
7. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY
Unless otherwise agreed in writing, any intellectual property created by the Developer in the performance of the Services shall be owned by Client.
8. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY 
Developer´s liability to the client is limited to the amount of the last invoice paid. Under no circumstance is the developer responsible for any indirect, consequential or punitive damage.
9. GOVERNING LAW
This Agreement shall be governed under the laws of the Client. 
10. ENTIRE AGREEMENT 
This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the parties with respect to the subject matter hereof and supersedes all prior agreements and understandings, whether written or oral.
This Agreement may be amended only by a written instrument signed by both parties.
10. SIGNATURES
This Statement of Work is agreed to and accepted by:
Client:
Name: _______________________
Signature: ___________________
Date: _______________________
Developer:
Name: _______________________
Signature: ___________________
Date: _______________________

contracts.extractedText:
STATEMENT OF WORK (SOW)
Proposal App Development
This SOW (“Agreement”) made and effective as of August 5th , 2024 (the “Effective Date”) by and between Swan Softweb Solutions , LLC (“Developer ”),, and Markman Group LLC (“Client”), sets forth the agreement whereby Developer agrees to provide services to Markman Group LLC pursuant to the terms and conditions herein. 
1. INTRODUCTION
This Statement of Work ("SOW") outlines the terms and conditions under which the Developer will provide software development services to the Client for the development of a Proposal App as described herein.
2. PROJECT OVERVIEW
The Developer will design, develop, and deliver a fully functional Proposal App according to the specifications detailed in the feature document and prototype previously agreed upon. The application will facilitate the creation of proposals through a streamlined process that includes authorization management, CAD file processing, task mapping, estimate generation, and proposal creation.
3. TIMELINE AND DELIVERABLES
3.1 Project Timeline
The project duration will be 9 weeks, commencing on August 5, 2025, with a final delivery date during the week of October 1, 2025.
3.2 Milestones and Deliverables
The project will be divided into the following milestones:
Milestone
Description
Estimated Completion
1
Authorizations and master data load
Week 2
2
CAD file upload and material list automatic generation
Week 4
3
Task mapping and estimate generation
Week 6
4
Proposal creation, proposal preview
Week 8
5
Final documents
Week 9



3.3 Acceptance Criteria
Each milestone will be considered complete when the Developer delivers the associated functionality according to the specifications in the feature document and prototype, and the Client approves the delivery through testing.
4. PAYMENT TERMS
4.1 Total Contract Value
The total payment for the development services will be $15,600.
4.2 Payment Schedule
Payments will be made at the completion of the project, 7 working days after the invoice delivery.
5. QUALITY ASSURANCE
5.1 Quality Requirements
All features described in the feature document and prototype must be included in the final deliverable. The Developer will conduct thorough testing before delivering each milestone to ensure compliance with the specifications.
5.2 Discrepancy Resolution
Any discrepancies between the delivered product and the specifications in the feature document and prototype must be resolved within 5 working days of identification by the Client.
5.3 Testing Period
The Client will have a two-months testing period following the final delivery to ensure all requirements specified in the feature document are met. The final payment is contingent upon successful completion of this testing period.
6. CHANGE MANAGEMENT
6.1 Change Request Process
Any changes to the project scope, timeline, or deliverables must be documented in a written Change Request and approved by both parties.
6.2 Impact Assessment
All Change Requests will include an assessment of the impact on the project timeline, deliverables, and cost.

7. COMMUNICATION
7.1 Regular Updates
The Developer will provide weekly progress updates to the Client, including:
	•	Completed tasks
	•	In-progress tasks
	•	Upcoming tasks
	•	Any issues or risks identified
7.2 Point of Contact
Each party will designate a primary point of contact for all project-related communications.
8. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY
All intellectual property rights to the developed software will transfer to the Client, including source code, documentation, and any other materials created for this project.
9. CONFIDENTIALITY AND NON-DISCLOSURE
9.1 Definition of Confidential Information
"Confidential Information" means all non-public information disclosed by either party ("Disclosing Party") to the other party ("Receiving Party"), whether orally, in writing, or by any other means, that is designated as confidential or that reasonably should be understood to be confidential given the nature of the information and the circumstances of disclosure. Confidential Information includes, but is not limited to:
	•	Business plans, strategies, forecasts, and analyses
	•	Financial information and projections
	•	Customer and supplier information
	•	Technical specifications, designs, drawings, and blueprints
	•	Software code, algorithms, and development methodologies
	•	Product plans, prototypes, and development roadmaps
	•	Marketing strategies and campaigns
	•	Employee and contractor information
	•	Trade secrets and proprietary technologies
	•	The terms and conditions of this SOW
9.2 Obligations of Receiving Party
The Receiving Party agrees to:
a) Use the Confidential Information solely for the purpose of performing its obligations under this SOW;
b) Protect the Confidential Information with the same degree of care it uses to protect its own confidential information, but in no event less than reasonable care;
c) Limit access to Confidential Information to its employees, contractors, and agents who have

STATEMENT OF WORK (SOW)
Rental App Development
This SOW (“Agreement”) made and effective as of January 6th, 2025 (the “Effective Date”) by and between Swan Softweb Solutions, LLC (“Developer ”),, and Markman Group LLC (“Client”), sets forth the agreement whereby Developer agrees to provide services to Markman Group LLC pursuant to the terms and conditions herein. 
1. INTRODUCTION
This Statement of Work ("SOW") outlines the terms and conditions under which the Developer will provide software development services to the Client for the development of a Rental Application as described herein.
2. PROJECT OVERVIEW
The Developer will design, develop, and deliver a fully functional Rental Application according to the specifications detailed in the feature document and prototype previously agreed upon. The application will facilitate full rental lifecycle, covering everything from order creation to return processing at the warehouse, enabling tracking of all essential checkpoints, stock management, and real-time reporting for operational control. Rental Application consists on three modules: 
	•	Rental Process Management: Covers the entire rental process from order creation to return processing. It allows manual adjustments when needed, ensuring flexibility and accuracy in handling rentals
	•	Warehouse Management: Tracks and manages the availability and usage of inventory in real-time. This module ensures accurate stock levels, preventing discrepancies, and supports manual adjustments when required.
	•	Reporting Module: The Reporting module provides high-level reports to track key rental operations and performance. These reports include essential data such as Revenue, Stock, Stock Movement, In Transit, Planned Removal, Planned Deliveries and Equipment Utilization)
3. TIMELINE AND DELIVERABLES
3.1 Project Timeline
The project duration will be 16 weeks, commencing on January 6, 2025, with a final delivery date during the week of April 21st, 2025 
3.2 Milestones and Deliverables
The project will be divided into the following milestones/sprints:
Milestone/
Sprint
Description
Estimated Completion

1
Authorisation, User Permission, User List(Authorization, Workflow and Master Data (Products/Warehouse)
Week 2 (2025.01.20)

2
Master Data (Account Managers, Customers), Stock Adjustment, Rent Process
Week 4 (2025.02.03)

3
Rent Process (Order and Recurring Order)
Week 6 (2025.02.17)

4
Rent Process (Return Order, Order Detail Stages: Create Delivery, Pickup Ticket and Check out)
Week 8 (2025.03.03)

5
Rent Process (Order Detail Stages: Delivered to Customer, Create Return Deliveries, Pickup Ticket for Return Delivery, Check In, Inspection Completed)
Week 10 (2025.03.15)

6
Global Search and Home – Map (Search, Zoom Controls, Full-Screen Mode, Street View integration, Location Pins& Home, Responsiveness and Error Handling)
Week 12 (2025.03.31)

7
Reports (Revenue Report, Stock Report, Stock Movement, In Transit)
Week 14
(2025.04.10)

8
Reports (Planned Removal, Planned Deliveries, Equipment Utilization Report) and Inbox (Request, Accept and Decline)
Week 16
(2025.04.21)

Upon final project completion, in addition to the delivery of all milestones, all related code documentation shall be provided.
3.3 Acceptance Criteria
Each milestone will be considered complete when the Developer delivers the associated functionality according to the specifications in the feature document and prototype, and the Client approves the delivery through testing.
4. PAYMENT TERMS
4.1 Total Contract Value
The total payment for the development services will be $15,720
4.2 Payment Schedule
The project's payment structure consists of two payments: 50% upon reaching the midpoint of all milestones, and the remaining 50% upon final project delivery.
5. QUALITY ASSURANCE
5.1 Quality Requirements
All features described in the feature document and prototype must be included in the final deliverable. The Developer will conduct thorough testing before delivering each milestone to ensure compliance with the specifications.
5.2 Discrepancy Resolution
Any discrepancies between the delivered product and the specifications in the feature document and prototype must be resolved within 5 working days of identification by the Client.
5.3 Testing Period
The Client will have a two-months testing period following the final delivery to ensure all requirements specified in the feature document are met. The final payment is contingent upon successful completion of this testing period.
6. CHANGE MANAGEMENT
6.1 Change Request Process
Any changes to the project scope, timeline, or deliverables must be documented in a written Change Request and approved by both parties.
6.2 Impact Assessment
All Change Requests will include an assessment of the impact on the project timeline, deliverables, and cost.
7. COMMUNICATION
7.1 Regular Updates
The Developer will provide weekly progress updates to the Client, including:
	•	Completed tasks
	•	In-progress tasks
	•	Upcoming tasks
	•	Any iss

contracts.extractedText:
LICENSING AND MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT


This Licensing and Maintenance Agreement is entered into between the Markman Group LLC, and LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC. This Agreement outlines the terms and conditions for the licensing, maintenance and support of the Laurel AG Web Application Platform. This document defines the scope of services, responsibilities, and associated costs.

	•	Scope of Services
This SOW covers the following services related to the Laurel AG Web Application Platform: 
	•	Licensing: Provisioning and management of the platform license and applications built on it.
	•	Maintenance: Routine maintenance, including server upkeep, security patches, bug fixes, and performance optimization.
	•	Support: Technical support for platform-related issues, including troubleshooting, issue resolution, and general platform guidance.
Note: Any change requests for new features, modifications to existing functionality, or custom development are explicitly out of scope for this SOW and will require a separate agreement.

	•	Platform and Applications Licensing 

	•	LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC will be granted a license to utilize the Laurel AG Web Application Platform.
	•	The base license covers the core platform functionality and infrastructure.
	•	The base platform licensing and maintenance will cost $5,000 USD per month.

	•	Application Licensing and Deployment

	•	The first application developed and deployed on the Laurel AG Web Application Platform is included at no additional cost.
	•	Each subsequent application deployed on the Laurel AG Web Application Platform will incur a monthly licensing and maintenance fee of $1,000 USD.

	•	Maintenance Services

In accordance with the terms of this Licensing and Maintenance Agreement, the Markman Group LLC will furnish the support and/or error-correction services identified for the cloud infrastructure hosting the Laurel AG Web Application Platform

	•	Maintenance Services:
	•	Regular server maintenance and monitoring.
	•	Security patch application and updates.
	•	Bug fixes and platform updates.
	•	Performance optimization and monitoring.
	•	Database maintenance and backups.
	•	Platform uptime monitoring.

	•	Maintenance Window: Routine maintenance is typically performed during off-peak hours to minimize service disruption. Advanced notice will be provided for any scheduled maintenance that may impact service availability.

	•	Support Services 

	•	Support Services:
	•	Technical support via email and a designated support portal: support@markmanassociates.com 
	•	Issue diagnosis and troubleshooting.
	•	Resolution of platform-related issues.

	•	Timeliness of Incident Resolution
The Markman Group LLC shall use reasonable effort to provide modifications or additions to correct errors in the Laurel AG Web Application Platform reported by LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC. 

Upon receipt of notice of an error, the Markman Group LLC will assign a priority level as determined by LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC to the error according to the following criteria:

	•	Priority A – An error that results in the Laurel AG Web Application Platform being substantially or completely nonfunctional or inoperative.
	•	Priority B – An error that results in the Laurel AG Web Application Platform operating or performing other than as represented in the Documentation, but which does not have a material adverse impact on the performance of the software.

The Markman Group LLC will make reasonable efforts to correct the error or provide a work-around solution for each priority level and, if a work-around is the immediate solution, will make reasonable efforts to provide a final resolution to the error.  Reasonable effort will be made to respond to the incident within the following time frames after receiving notice and sufficient information and support from LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC:

Priority Level
Correction or Work-Around 
If Work-Around, Final Resolution
A
2 business days
7 business days
B
5 business days
10 business days

	•	Client (LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC) Cooperation: 
The level of support that the Markman Group LLC can provide is dependent upon the cooperation of LAUREL AG & WATER and the quantity of information that LAUREL AG & WATER can provide. 

LAUREL AG & WATER can report errors to the following mailbox: support@markmanassociates.com 

If the Markman Group LLC cannot reproduce a problem or if LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC cannot successfully gather adequate troubleshooting information, the Markman Group LLC may need temporary login access on the LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC system to identify and address the problem.


	•	Location Where Services will be rendered

Services will be rendered remotely 

	•	Responsibilities

	•	Client (LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC) Responsibilities: 
	•	Providing accurate and timely information for issue resolution.
	•	Adhering to platform usage guidelines.
	•	Paying all invoiced fees in a timely fashion.
	•	Providing proper access to application-related logs and environments when needed for support.
	•

contracts.extractedText:
LICENSING AND MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT

This Licensing and Maintenance Agreement is entered into between the Markman Group LLC, and LAUREL AG & WATER, LLC, hereinafter referred to as "the RECIPIENT."  
The RECIPIENT wishes to engage the Markman Group LLC to perform various maintenance services in connection with the cloud infrastructure hosting the Rental & Proposal application.

	•	License to Client

Markman Group LLC grants to Laurel AG a non-exclusive, perpetual, worldwide license to use the Application, subject to the terms and conditions outlined in this agreement. This license is effective upon delivery of the Application to Laurel AG.

	•	Maintenance Services

In accordance with the terms of this Licensing and Maintenance Agreement, the Markman Group LLC will furnish the support and/or error-correction services identified for the cloud infrastructure hosting the Rental & Proposal applications.

2.  Maintenance Fee and Expenses

	The RECIPIENT will pay the Markman Group LLC the agreed monthly fee of $3,000 within thirty (30) days of the Commencement Date agreed by both parties. If payment for the full 12-month term is paid within 30 days from receiving the invoice, a 15% discount will apply, with a yearly cost of $30,600. The RECIPIENT shall pay the Markman Group LLC for services outside the scope of this Maintenance Agreement on a time and material basis at Markman Group LLC then-prevailing rates, and only with RECIPIENT’s prior written approval. 

     Should the requirement originate for any additional services or resources to be hosted and maintained on the Markman Group LLC Azure Cloud infrastructure, the request will be reviewed, and an additional maintenance cost will be agreed on.

Upon termination of this Licensing and Maintenance Agreement, the Markman Group LLC will be reimbursed for all reasonable costs and non-cancelable commitments incurred in the performance of the scope of work and for which the RECIPIENT has not yet paid. 
3.  Term and Termination

	•	Term.  This Licensing and Maintenance Agreement shall commence on the Commencement Date stated in Supplement A and continue for an initial period defined in Supplement A (“Initial Term”).  This Licensing and Maintenance Agreement shall thereafter auto renew every 12 months unless terminated by either party upon written notice, thirty (30) days prior to planned termination date.  

 (b)  Termination.  This Licensing and Maintenance Agreement shall terminate within thirty (30) days upon receipt of an advance written notice provided by the RECIPIENT to Markman Group LLC.


4.  Recipient Support

The level of support that the Markman Group LLC can provided is dependent upon the cooperation of RECIPIENT and the quantity of information that RECIPIENT can provide.  RECIPIENT can report errors to the following mailbox: support@markmangroup.freshdesk.com

If the Markman Group LLC cannot reproduce a problem or if the RECIPIENT cannot successfully gather adequate troubleshooting information, the Markman Group LLC may need temporary login access on the RECIPIENT’s system to identify and address the problem.


5.	Right to Work Product  All error corrections, enhancements, new releases, and any other work product created by the Markman Group LLC in connection with the support services provided under this Licensing and Maintenance Agreement are and shall remain the exclusive property of the Markman Group LLC.
 

Supplement A


Coverage of Maintenance Agreement

The Azure services covered by this Licensing and Maintenance Agreement is as follows:
	•	Azure App Service for hosting and scaling web applications and APIs, ensuring high availability and performance. 
	•	Infrastructure as a Service is cloud hosting services that include compute, storage and networking resources in demand.
	•	Azure Database for PostgreSQL is a managed database service to handle transactional workloads with high availability, scalability, and security. 
	•	Azure Application Insights for application performance management, enabling monitoring, diagnostics, and analytics to optimize performance and user experience. 
	•	Azure Key Vault for managing secrets, encryption keys, and certificates, enhancing the security posture and compliance. 

Here is a detailed explanation of how the system will handle requests and manage data flow:

Request Handling:

Application Hosting:
	•	Azure App Services: Validated requests are then routed to Azure App Services, which hosts web applications. Azure App Services provides a scalable and managed platform for deploying web applications.

Database Interaction:
	•	Azure Database for PostgreSQL: When a request needs to interact with the database, it is securely passed through a private network. This is facilitated by VNet integration in Azure App Services and the creation of a Private Endpoint for the database, ensuring secure and private communication. 

Secure Data Access:
	•	Azure Key Vault and Storage Account: If the application requires access to sec

proposals.sharepointPath: /General/Offerings & Projects/1. Tailored Application Development/Laurel_AG - Proposal and Rental Tools/Working Files/Documentation/Laurel Proposal Features.pdf

/General/Offerings & Projects/1. Tailored Application Development/Laurel_AG - Proposal and Rental Tools/Working Files/LaurelAG-ClientPortal/Proposal Application/Feature Documentation/Laurel Proposal Features.docx
proposals.extractedText:
Laurel Features
Authorization
Login
	•	We will add authorization screen where admin can manage users like adding user, update users and enable or disabled user account. Adin will be able also to assign additional admin users.
	•	Users can login via Microsoft account.








View
Full Screen View
	•	Users can switch to full screen mode by clicking on the maximize screen icon located at the top.

	•	Users can exit full screen mode by clicking on the minimize screen icon located at the top.


Side Panel View
	•	Users can collapse the sidebar by clicking on the right pointed arrow.
	•	This feature is present in all the screens.

Default View
	•	The default view is visible at the start of the page.
	•	Users can see the full sidebar by moving mouse cursor on the sidebar panel.
	•	This feature is present in all the screens.

Global Search
	•	Users can globally search for opportunities based on Document Number as user types, based on the matched keywords data will float at bottom.
	•	After clicking on that data, the user will get redirected to appropriate opportunity details.




Product List
Import Product
	•	Users can import product data from the CSV Master Data sheet.
	•	We'll build a search function like in excel.
	•	When users import master data for a product, we verify the data and will display a notice such as "Please enter valid file" if the data does not match the requirements of file.

List View
	•	Users can see the list of all imported products with sorting & searching capabilities.

Labor Cost List
Import Labor 
	•	Users can import labor data from the CSV Master Data sheet.
	•	We'll build a search function like in excel.
	•	When users import master data for a labor, we verify the data and will display a notice such as "Please enter valid file" if the data does not match the requirements of file.

List View
	•	Users can see the list of all imported labors with sorting & searching capabilities.

Customer List
Import Customer 
	•	Users can import customer data from the CSV Master Data sheet.
	•	We'll build a search function like in excel.
	•	When users import master data for a Customer, we verify the data and will display a notice such as "Please enter valid file" if the data does not match the requirements of file.

List View
	•	Users can see the list of all imported customers with sorting & searching capabilities.

Task List
Import Task 
	•	Users can import task data from the CSV Master Data sheet.
	•	We'll build a search function like in excel.
	•	When users import master data for a Taks, we verify the data and will display a notice such as "Please enter valid file" if the data does not match the requirements of file.

List View
	•	Users can see the list of all imported tasks with sorting & searching capabilities.


Vendor List
Import Vendor 
	•	Users can import vendor data from the CSV Master Data sheet.
	•	We'll build a search function like in excel.
	•	When users import master data for a Vendor, we verify the data and will display a notice such as "Please enter valid file" if the data does not match the requirements of file.

List View
	•	Users can see the list of all imported vendors with sorting & searching capabilities.


Opportunity List
Import Opportunity 
	•	Users can import opportunity data from the CSV Master Data sheet.
	•	We'll build a search function like in excel.
	•	When users import master data for the Opportunity, we verify the data and will display a notice such as "Please enter valid file" if the data does not match the requirements of file.
	•	We will have option to search/filter by all fields (dropdown, auto populate from master)
	•	Master data fields for opportunity list will be document number, designer, estimator, pump & electrical designer, design/estimation notes and we will include also fields generated by app such as next stage of the estimation process and last update date. In case the opportunity was only imported from Netsuite and estimate process did not start yet, the last update will be date when import has taken place.
	•	Opportunities which were previously loaded and are included in the current load, will have only last update date modified with date of latest load.

List View
	•	Users can see the list of all imported opportunities with sorting & searching capabilities.
	•	Users can open many opportunities on different tab or window by right click on opportunity number or click + cmd.

 
View Documents  
	•	Users can view the list of all uploaded documents across all 8 stages.
	•	If opportunity reach to 7 stage, we display icon to view four documents of stage 8 (Print Proposal, New Material Master data,Costs Variances, Netsuite Extracts) 



Estimation process

	•	To move on to the next stage the user will have to complete the current stage.
	•	Users can move to any tab any time if stage that stage completed.

Select Task Code
	•	Users can add task based on imported Task

	•	Users can search task by task name and description while add task.




	•	Users can see all

proposals.filename: Laurel CRM SF integration to Proposal Application - proposal V01.docx
proposals.localPath: data/projects/laurel-ag-proposal-tools/proposals/Laurel CRM SF integration to Proposal Application - proposal V01.docx
proposals.sharepointPath: /General/Proposals/Laurel HSFD/Laurel CRM SF integration to Proposal Application - proposal V01.docx
proposals.extractedText:
1. Project Overview and Strategic Objectives
Project Overview
The objective of this project is to integrate an Azure-based Proposal Application with Salesforce, enabling seamless automation of proposal creation and management. The integration aims to remove manual data entry by establishing automated data synchronization between the two systems, with both automatic and manual options available.
This project includes three modules:
	•	Module 1: Adjustments to the Proposal Application to automatically create proposals when opportunities in Salesforce reach the Proposal Prep phase. This is the foundational module upon which the rest of the system relies.
	•	Module 2: Salesforce customization to receive and display data pushed from the Proposal Application once proposals are created or updated in the Proposal Application.
	•	Module 3: A manual data upload option for the Proposal Application, allowing Salesforce to receive data via CSV/TXT file uploads if automatic syncing is not preferred.
The client will need to choose between Module 2 and Module 3 depending on their preference for automated or manual data synchronization.
Strategic Objectives
The following six objectives focus primarily on Module 1 and Module 2, as these are foundational for automating the workflow and integrating data across platforms:
	•	Streamline Proposal Management: Automate the synchronization of proposal data between the Proposal Application and Salesforce when opportunities reach specific stages, reducing manual entry.
	•	Optimize Workflow Efficiency: By automating the creation and management of proposals in Salesforce, the process will become faster and more reliable, minimizing the chances of errors.
	•	Enhance Data Integrity: Automatically synchronized data will be validated and standardized across both platforms, ensuring accuracy in reporting and decision-making.
	•	User-Friendly Interfaces: Ensure that all proposal data, including fields like Material Cost, Labor Cost, and Total Sale, is accessible and editable within Salesforce, improving user interaction and experience.
	•	Seamless Integration: Implement an API-driven connection between Salesforce and the Proposal Application, enabling real-time, bidirectional data flow.
	•	Data Security and Compliance: Ensure that all data exchanged between the Proposal Application and Salesforce is secure, using OAuth 2.0 for authentication and protecting sensitive financial data.

 
2. Project Methodology
This project will be executed following an agile methodology, ensuring flexibility, transparency, and consistent feedback from stakeholders at all stages. This approach will allow us to respond to changing requirements or preferences quickly.
Phases:
	•	Current State Assessment: We will perform an initial analysis of existing systems and workflows, identify pain points, and document all data fields and processes that need to be integrated between the Proposal Application and Salesforce.
	•	Key Activities:
	•	Discovery sessions with stakeholders.
	•	Mapping of current Salesforce Opportunity data fields.
	•	Analyzing existing Proposal Application workflows and APIs.
	•	Outcome: A detailed As-Is Discovery Report that outlines integration gaps, current workflows, and data flows, along with recommendations for improvements.
	•	Solution Design: This phase will focus on architecting a solution that bridges the Proposal Application and Salesforce seamlessly. This will involve defining data mappings, setting up APIs, and designing the Salesforce UI.
	•	Key Activities:
	•	Designing APIs for Proposal Application adjustments (Module 1).
	•	Creating new Salesforce data models and UI components (Module 2).
	•	Drafting a detailed technical blueprint for integration.
	•	Outcome: A comprehensive Solution Design Document that details the technical architecture, API connections, UI design for Salesforce, and data flow processes.
	•	Development and Implementation: During this phase, our development team will build and implement the designed solution. The Proposal Application will be adjusted, Salesforce will be customized, and both systems will be integrated. Full testing will be conducted to ensure the solution functions as intended.
	•	Key Activities:
	•	Implementing API connections between the Proposal Application and Salesforce.
	•	Customizing Salesforce with new fields, triggers, and data flows.
	•	Developing the manual data upload functionality (Module 3).
	•	Full system testing, including UAT (User Acceptance Testing).
	•	Outcome: A fully functional, integrated solution with verified functionality and minimal defects.
	•	Phased Rollout: The solution will be deployed in a phased manner, starting with a pilot phase for a small group of users. Based on the feedback from the pilot phase, we will iterate and refine the solution before rolling it out to the entire organization.
	•	Key Activities:
	•	Running a pilot with a selected group of users.
	•	Gathering user feedback and making necessary adjustments.

Technical Specification for Rental Process Application

Database Structure: laurel_rental_application
The database structure outlined below serves as the foundational framework for the Rental Process Application. This structure is designed to efficiently manage all aspects of the rental process, including inventory management, customer data, order processing, and user roles. While the following tables are critical to the application's functionality, additional tables can be added as per development needs.
	•	Table: warehouse_product_list

Description:
This table stores information about the equipment available in the warehouse, including their identification, material grouping, and subtypes for accounting or classification purposes.
Columns:
	•	equipment_id - INT - PRIMARY KEY, AUTO_INCREMENT
	•	A unique identifier for each piece of equipment.
	•	equipment_material_group - VARCHAR(255)
	•	A text-based category representing the material group to which the equipment belongs
	•	equipment_name - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The name or description of the equipment (e.g., "TV," "Laser Cutter").
	•	subtype - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The subtype of the equipment, which categorizes it further for purposes such as accounting or inventory management.
	•	last_updated_by – VARCHAR(255) - NOT NULL
	•	The user_id of the user who last updated this record.


Table Structure Example:
CREATE TABLE warehouse_product_list (
equipment_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT, equipment_material_group VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, equipment_name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
subtype VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
last_updated_by VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
FOREIGN KEY (last_updated_by) REFERENCES user_list(user_id)
);

Notes:

The equipment_material_group column now stores descriptive text labels that categorize the equipment.
The subtype column remains for additional classification purposes, useful for accounting or organizational needs.

	•	Table: warehouse_list
Description:
This table stores information about the various warehouse locations, including their names and addresses.
Columns:
	•	location_id - INT - PRIMARY KEY, AUTO_INCREMENT
	•	A unique identifier for each warehouse location.
	•	location_name - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The name or designation of the warehouse location (e.g., "Bakersfield," "Brawley").
	•	address - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The full address of the warehouse, including street address, city, state, and ZIP code.
	•	latitude: Latitude of the warehouse location.
	•	longitude: Longitude of the warehouse location.
	•	last_updated_by – VARCHAR(255) - NOT NULL
	•	The user_id of the user who last updated this record.

Table Structure Example:
CREATE TABLE warehouse_list (
location_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT, location_name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, address VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL
last_updated_by VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
FOREIGN KEY (last_updated_by) REFERENCES user_list(user_id)
);

Notes:
	•	The location_id column is a unique, auto-incremented identifier for each warehouse, ensuring that each location can be uniquely referenced.
	•	The location_name column stores the name or designation of the warehouse, which may reflect
its geographic location or other identifying features.
	•	The address column is a text field that stores the complete address of each warehouse, making it easy to locate or reference specific warehouses.

	•	Table: account_managers

Description:
This table stores information about account managers, including their names and email addresses. Columns:
	•	manager_id - INT - PRIMARY KEY, AUTO_INCREMENT
	•	A unique identifier for each account manager.
	•	manager_name - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The full name of the account manager (e.g., "Brawley Smith," "Brooke Marchy").
	•	email_address - VARCHAR(255) - UNIQUE
	•	The email address of the account manager.
	•	last_updated_by – VARCHAR(255) - NOT NULL
	•	The user_id of the user who last updated this record.

Table Structure Example:
CREATE TABLE account_managers (
manager_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
manager_name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, email_address VARCHAR(255) UNIQUE NOT NULL last_updated_by VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
FOREIGN KEY (last_updated_by) REFERENCES user_list(user_id)
);

Notes:
	•	The manager_id column is a unique, auto-incremented identifier for each account manager.
	•	The manager_name column stores the full name of the account manager.
	•	The email_address column is designed to be unique to prevent duplicate email entries and ensure that each manager's email is distinct.

	•	Table: customer_list
Description:
This table stores information about customers, including their internal ID, customer ID, name . Columns:
	•	internal_id - INT - PRIMARY KEY, AUTO_INCREMENT
	•	A unique internal identifier for each customer.
	•	customer_id - VARCHAR(50) - UNIQUE
	•	A unique customer identifier used within the system (e.g., "C006383").
	•	last_updated_by – VARCHAR(255) - NOT NULL

	•	The user_id of the user who last updated this record.

Table Structure Example:
CREATE TABLE customer_list (
internal_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INC

documentation.filename: Rental Application_Technical Specification for CRs Pending Inspection, Multiple Locations & Stock Report.docx
documentation.localPath: data/projects/laurel-ag-proposal-tools/documentation/Rental Application_Technical Specification for CRs Pending Inspection, Multiple Locations & Stock Report.docx
documentation.sharepointPath: /General/Offerings & Projects/1. Tailored Application Development/Laurel_AG - Proposal and Rental Tools/Working Files/Working Folder_Nikoleta/Laurel_Rental Application_Documenation/Rental Application_Technical Specification for CRs Pending Inspection, Multiple Locations & Stock Report.docx
documentation.extractedText:
Inspection Pending, Multiple Delivery Locations Features & Stock Report

	•	Inspection Pending (Out of Stock)
Overview: 
In the context of out of stock items, the Pending Inspection Report will be more granular, allowing different teams (based on their warehouse) to view, track, and take action on inspections pending for out-of-stock materials.
Inspection Completion Stage:
In the inspection stage, users will have the option to complete the inspection for each material individually or in bulk.
	•	Individual Completion: Users can select a single item or multiple items and mark it as inspected. This option allows for more detailed tracking and manual verification for each material.
	•	Bulk Completion: As is currently available, users will be able complete the inspection for all materials at once. This option is ideal for handling large volumes of items at once, improving efficiency.
Report for Warehouse-Based Visibility:
	•	Warehouse-Specific Pending Inspection Report:
	•	The report will be filtered and organized by warehouse, providing clear visibility to the team members responsible for each location.
	•	Each warehouse will have its own set of out-of-stock materials pending inspection, allowing teams to focus on their specific area and increase operational efficiency.
	•	Report Filters:
	•	Users will be able to filter the report by warehouse, ensuring that they only see the relevant pending items for inspection that pertain to their specific location.
	•	Tracking by Days Pending:
	•	Materials will be tracked based on how many days they have been pending for inspection.
	•	Red Flagging by Warehouse: If an item has been pending for more than 2 days, it will be flagged in red to draw attention for immediate action.
	•	Warehouse-Specific Responsibilities:
	•	Warehouse teams will be able to directly manage the items in their warehouse by checking their report, ensuring that pending inspections are handled in a timely manner.

	•	Dashboard Integration:
	•	A dashboard view will provide quick access to performance data regarding pending inspections across multiple warehouses.
	•	Dashboard Header to include:
	•	Warehouse Name
	•	Number of pending inspections by warehouse
	•	Number of items overdue (red-flagged) by warehouse
	•	Average days pending per warehouse
	•	Detailed Reports could include:
	•	Order Number
	•	Return Delivery Number (hyperlinked to inspection within the rental process)
	•	Item ID
	•	Item Name
	•	Contract End Date
	•	Check In Date
	•	Days Overdue (flagged red if overdue)
	•	Notes
	•	Action Button (complete inspection or do stock adjustment)
User Interface (UI) Updates for Warehouse Visibility:
	•	Report Page for Pending Inspections:
	•	Users can select a warehouse from a dropdown or filter bar at the top of the report page.
	•	Once a warehouse is selected, the data will be filtered to show only the relevant pending inspection items.
	•	Color Coding and Alerts by Location:
	•	The red flagging of overdue inspections will be visually represented with different color highlights by location, making it easy to identify which warehouse has the most pressing issues.
	•	Location-Specific Notifications:
	•	Reminder notifications for pending inspections will be sent daily, ensuring the right teams are notified about pending inspections in their area. These reminders will be triggered based on the location’s due dates.
 
Report Access:
	•	User Feedback:
	•	Users will be able to add comments or notes related to pending inspections, which can be reviewed by warehouse managers. This ensures that any additional context (e.g., inspection delays) is captured and tracked, improving communication and transparency.
	•	Warehouse Base Access:
	•	New role for warehouse pending inspection report to be created.

 
	•	Multiple Delivery Locations
Overview:
The Multiple Delivery Locations feature will allow the user to specify multiple delivery locations for both delivery and return processes. This will streamline logistics and improve the delivery experience for customers with multiple locations.

Key Components:
	•	Multiple Deliveries for Different Locations:
	•	Option 1 – Multiple Deliveries: The user can create multiple deliveries, each with a different delivery address, within the selected range or customer location.
	•	Option 2 – Single Delivery with Multiple Locations: As an alternative, the user can select multiple locations during the creation of a single delivery. This option simplifies the process by avoiding multiple entries and allowing all locations to be grouped under one delivery record.
	•	Return Delivery Integration:
	•	The selected multiple locations during the delivery creation process will also be reflected in the return delivery process. This ensures consistency and accurate tracking throughout the entire rental period.
	•	Free Text Notes for Each Location:
	•	Customizable Notes: For each location added, the user will have the option to add free text notes. These notes will allow for detailed instruction

	•	A text-based category representing the material group to which the equipment belongs
	•	equipment_name - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The name or description of the equipment (e.g., "TV," "Laser Cutter").
	•	subtype - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The subtype of the equipment, which categorizes it further for purposes such as accounting or inventory management.
	•	last_updated_by – VARCHAR(255) - NOT NULL
	•	The user_id of the user who last updated this record.


Table Structure Example:
CREATE TABLE warehouse_product_list (
equipment_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT, equipment_material_group VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, equipment_name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
subtype VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
last_updated_by VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
FOREIGN KEY (last_updated_by) REFERENCES user_list(user_id)
);

Notes:

The equipment_material_group column now stores descriptive text labels that categorize the equipment.
The subtype column remains for additional classification purposes, useful for accounting or organizational needs.

	•	Table: warehouse_list
Description:
This table stores information about the various warehouse locations, including their names and addresses.
Columns:
	•	location_id - INT - PRIMARY KEY, AUTO_INCREMENT
	•	A unique identifier for each warehouse location.
	•	location_name - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The name or designation of the warehouse location (e.g., "Bakersfield," "Brawley").
	•	address - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The full address of the warehouse, including street address, city, state, and ZIP code.
	•	latitude: Latitude of the warehouse location.
	•	longitude: Longitude of the warehouse location.
	•	last_updated_by – VARCHAR(255) - NOT NULL
	•	The user_id of the user who last updated this record.

Table Structure Example:
CREATE TABLE warehouse_list (
location_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT, location_name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, address VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL
last_updated_by VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
FOREIGN KEY (last_updated_by) REFERENCES user_list(user_id)
);

Notes:
	•	The location_id column is a unique, auto-incremented identifier for each warehouse, ensuring that each location can be uniquely referenced.
	•	The location_name column stores the name or designation of the warehouse, which may reflect
its geographic location or other identifying features.
	•	The address column is a text field that stores the complete address of each warehouse, making it easy to locate or reference specific warehouses.

	•	Table: account_managers

Description:
This table stores information about account managers, including their names and email addresses. Columns:
	•	manager_id - INT - PRIMARY KEY, AUTO_INCREMENT
	•	A unique identifier for each account manager.
	•	manager_name - VARCHAR(255)
	•	The full name of the account manager (e.g., "Brawley Smith," "Brooke Marchy").
	•	email_address - VARCHAR(255) - UNIQUE
	•	The email address of the account manager.
	•	last_updated_by – VARCHAR(255) - NOT NULL
	•	The user_id of the user who last updated this record.

Table Structure Example:
CREATE TABLE account_managers (
manager_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
manager_name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, email_address VARCHAR(255) UNIQUE NOT NULL last_updated_by VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
FOREIGN KEY (last_updated_by) REFERENCES user_list(user_id)
);

Notes:
	•	The manager_id column is a unique, auto-incremented identifier for each account manager.
	•	The manager_name column stores the full name of the account manager.
	•	The email_address column is designed to be unique to prevent duplicate email entries and ensure that each manager's email is distinct.
